option.value: Module 3 - The Specific Requirements for Light and Heavy Equipment

string_table.name: pxabnsnfns11111101111
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.
You must complete the question before submitting.
Enter your name in the field below:
You have reached the time limit set for the quiz. Press 'OK' to continue.

slidelink.displaytext: Module 3: The Specific Requirements for Light and Heavy Equipment
Principles for Securing Automobiles, Light Trucks, and Vans
Tie Down Requirements for Automobiles, Light Trucks, and Vans
Securing Heavy Vehicles, Equipment, and Machinery Activity
Tie Down Requirements for Heavy Vehicles, Equipment and Machinery

search.slidetext: cargo securement module 3: the specific requirements for light and heavy equipment start start start

tie downs designed to fit over or around wheels of vehicle being transported must provide restraint: side-to-side forward and rearward vertically tie downs that are designed to be attached directly to structure of vehicle being transported must use vehicle securement mounting points. click tie downs affixed to transport vehicle structure and tie downs designed to fit over/around wheels to learn about the tie down requirements for automobiles, light trucks, and vans. tie downs affixed to transport vehicle structure tie downs affixed to transport vehicle structure tie downs affixed to transport vehicle structure tie downs designed to fit over/around wheels tie downs designed to fit over/around wheels tie downs designed to fit over/around wheels

incorrect. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct. continue continue continue continue continue continue true true true true true true false false false false false false tie downs that are directly attached to the vehicle being transported are the most effective. true or false? following the cargo securement standard

incorrect. here are the correct answers. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct. continue continue continue continue continue continue common failure modes for automobiles, light trucks, and vans, what are the two failure modes you avoid by planning the correct securement system? drag and drop the correct responses and click the submit button. sliding traction loss rolling visual distraction

common failure modes incorrect. here are the correct answers. continue continue continue continue continue continue for automobiles, light trucks, and vans, what are the two failure modes you avoid by planning the correct securement system? drag and drop the correct responses and click the submit button. sliding traction loss rolling visual distraction

for automobiles, light trucks, and vans you must use a minimum of two (2) tie downs to restrain the front and rear. remember, you may need more than two tie downs to satisfy the general requirements. incorrect. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct. continue continue continue continue continue continue 2 2 2 2 2 2 4 4 4 4 4 4 8 8 8 8 8 8 what is the minimum number of tie downs required that must be used to restrain the front and rear of an automobile, light truck, or van? 1 1 1 1 1 1 select the correct answer and click submit.

incorrect. the correct answers are shown. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct. continue continue continue continue continue continue there are three primary cargo securement failure modes for heavy vehicles, equipment, and machinery and a variety of tools and methods to help avoid these failure modes. drag and drop each word or phrase to the correct location. sliding (with vibration along trailer bed) rolling tipping or swinging of accessory equipment parking brakes tie downs attached to cargo tie downs that go over cargo other mechanical braking methods failure modes ways to immobilize equipment or accessories

there are three primary cargo securement failure modes for heavy vehicles, equipment, and machinery and a variety of tools and methods to help avoid these failure modes. drag and drop each word or phrase to the correct location. sliding (with vibration along trailer bed) tipping or swinging of accessory equipment rolling other mechanical braking methods parking brakes tie downs attached to cargo tie downs that go over cargo incorrect. the correct answers are shown. continue continue continue continue continue continue failure modes ways to immobilize equipment or accessories

incorrect. the correct answers are shown. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct. continue continue continue continue continue continue cargo must be restrained to avoid movement in four directions. drag and drop the correct directions to complete the diagram. forward side-to-side vertically rearward right horizontal

cargo must be restrained to avoid movement in four directions. drag and drop the correct directions to complete the diagram. forward side-to-side vertically rearward right horizontal incorrect. here are the correct answers. continue continue continue continue continue continue

this is false. more tie downs may be necessary to satisfy the requirements of the general cargo securement standard. remember: “the aggregate working load limit of any securement system used to secure an article or group of articles against movement must be at least one-half times the weight of the article or group of articles.” incorrect. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct. continue continue continue continue continue continue true true true true true true false false false false false false true or false? you only need four tie downs to satisfy the general requirements of the cargo securement standard. select the correct answer and click submit.
exit exit exit exit exit exit well done! you may now exit this module.
